Validation

Lesson
objectives

¢ Distinguish between field-level validation

configuration in the user interface and the
data model

Describe how an input mask differs from a
regular expression

Create and use an entity field validator
Describe basic validation rule behavior
Create validation rules that raise warnings
and errors

i User Story — Policy Number Format Gi

“The insurance company has a very specific policy number format: two letters, a
hyphen, and seven digits. We want this format to be enforced when the policy is
being saved. The same format must be used when the policy is saved from the UI or
through API calls. In the Ul, a watermark should be displayed to guide the users. If
the policy number format is incorrect then the following error message should be
displayed: Policy Number must be a valid policy number. Example: AA-1234567"

— Insurance company business analysts

About Pattern Matching

i Pattern matching

¢ Pattern matching is a field-level validation technique

¢ Verifies that the user entered the data in the correct format for that field
¢ E.g.: tax id must be a nine-digit number with hyphens after the third and fifth digits
* Prevents the user from saving invalid business data

* Could be implemented in the data model or the UI tier

« Main components:
« Regular expression
* Input mask (optional)

i Pattern matching - regular expressions Gi

¢ Aregular expression defines an abstract pattern
¢ Examples:

« Email address: ot@.t\. et
« Routing number: [0-9a-zA-Z] {3}-[0-9] {3}
Details

Validation errors on current page: i)

@ Routing Number: Must be 3 alphanumerics, a hyphen, and 3 digits.

Savings | Pending

i Pattern matching — input masks

¢ Appears as a watermark in field and mouse over

tooltip

* Changes to a darker color with data entry

* No format warning

* Does not restrict data commit but instead guides the

user to input the data in a certain format

mnemoue
inputConversion
inputMask
Inhelahove.

‘outputConversion

FequestValidationExpression

falee

es)

i Pattern matching- practices comparison

Data model User interface.
¢ Pros * Pros
¢ Application enforces compliance in the ¢ Dynamic values: regex and input mask
UI and through API can change based on business logic
* Supports full localization * Can restrict data commit
¢ Robust extensibility ¢ Cons
* Cons * Only a few widget support it
* Static values only: regex and input « Must be configured per widget

mask cannot change based on * No custom error message option
business logic

« Extensibility a big concern
¢ Implemented as a reusable field ya bia

validator ¢ Implemented as widget properties

i Example: pattern matching in the Ul

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

i User Story — High-value policy Gi

“We want TrainingApp to warn the users when they are saving a high-value
(Premium greater than $5000) California policy.

The following warning message should be displayed when trying to save the policy:
This is a high-value California policy!

The second time, after warning the user, the save should be allowed.”

— Insurance company business analysts

i Business logic — validation expression Gi

« Avvalidation expression is a logical Gosu expression associated with a single
atomic widget that implements field-level validation

¢ If expression returns null, save is allowed

¢ If expression returns string (an error message), then save is prevented, field is flagged, and
message is displayed at top of screen

¢ Configured as a widget property in the UI tier

i Business logic — validation expression (continued) Gi

¢ Input validated on update and invalid value stops commit
Invalid field value shows red box warning
* Mouse over the field to see the invalid value in field error message
* Message bar localizable error displayed

* requestValidationExpression property is similar

« It validates the user input on update AND on every other server request (e.g.: when navigating
to a different page)

i Example: business logic — validationExpression Gi
A

i Business logic — validation rules Gi

¢ Validation rules are written as Gosu rules and contain logic to validate (complex)
logical conditions and/or relationships between entity fields

¢ E.g.: primary phone number must be selected if the user has more than one phone numbers
« Validation rules can be used to:

* Ensure that the user enters data that makes sense

« Ensure that the user enters all necessary data

« Manage relationships between data fields

i Business logic — validation rules

« Business rules can show warnings or errors
¢ Validation during saved

* Checked when Validatable entity is committed to the database
¢ Entity must implement the Validatable delegate

* implementsEntity tag in the ETI/ETX file

i Delegates Gi

« Adelegate models a capability and allows sharing functionality across the data
model

¢« Examples:
« Any entity implementing the Validatable delegate can be validated by Gosu rules

« Any entity implementing the Assignable delegate can be automatically assigned to a user and
user group by Gosu rules

¢ Technically a delegate is a virtual object defined in the data model
« It consists of database fields and/or methods that can be reused by multiple entities
« Anentity can implement multiple delegates

i Delegate examples Gi

¢ Validatable delegate defines reusable functions to show warning or error
messages

¢ Assignable delegate contains functions to perform the assignment and database
fields to store the assignment details (AssignedUser, AssignedTime)

i Validation graph

¢ The rules engine performs validation during database commit
¢ Validation is triggered when:
¢ Validatable object is created or changed

¢ Validatable sub-object is created, changed, or removed

* "triggersValidation" attribute on the foreign key or array controls this behavior

i Validation graph

¢ The rules engine performs validation during database commit
¢ Validation is triggered when:
¢ Validatable object is created or changed

¢ Validatable sub-object is created, changed, or removed

* "triggersValidation" attribute on the foreign key or array controls this behavior

i Business logic — practices comparison Gi

¢ Validates a simple logical condition ¢ Validates complex logical
for a single field relationships between entity fields
¢ Implemented in the UI and must be ¢ Entity must implement the
configured per widget Validatable delegate in the data
model

¢ Application enforces compliance in
the UI and through the APIs

i Demonstration G
High value policy

click here

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

Question G

_— — Assume that there is an Order entity that has an OrderNumber field. The
Pa field appears on two detail views: LegacyOrdersDV and NewOrdersDV.

A) Name a situation where you would implement validation logic for the
OrderNumber field at the data model level.

B) Name a situation where you would implement validation logic for the
OrderNumber field at the UI level.

Se Sess e ese ssc esaeK

Answer Gi

_— — Assume that there is an Order entity that has an OrderNumber field. The
Pa field appears on two detail views: LegacyOrdersDV and NewOrdersDV.
¢

A) Name a situation where you would implement validation logic for the

OrderNumber field at the data model level.

B) Name a situation where you would implement validation logic for the
OrderNumber field at the UI level.

A) Possible answer: The OrderNumber field has a pattern, such as two characters, a
hyphen, and five characters, and this pattern must be followed everywhere the
field is used. Also, you want to localize the error message.

B) Possible answer: On the detail view for orders imported from a legacy system, the
order number could take any format. On the detail view for orders created in the
Guidewire application, the order number must start with the characters "GW-*.

SS Se SSeS sess e eases

Question

_— — What happens if a widget's validation expression retums null?

¢
¢
4

Se Sess e ese ssc esaeK

Answer

a What happens if a widget's validation expression retums null?

¢
¢

The save is allowed—a return value of null signifies that the validation condition was
met.

SS Se SSeS sess e eases

Question G

_- — Incase of validation rules, if you have an existing reject statement which

Pa raises only a warning, how would you change it to instead raise an error?

4

Se Sess e ese ssc esaeK

Answer Gi

_- — Incase of validation rules, if you have an existing reject statement which
Pa raises only a warning, how would you change it to instead raise an error?
¢

You would swap the order of the final two pairs of arguments. The first pair should be
the last pair and vice versa.

SS Se SSeS sess e eases

Question

,— — the first argument of rejectField is a “relative path” to the object to
Pa highlight. Why is it relevant to keep in mind that the path is relative?

Se Sess e ese ssc esaeK

Answer

,— — the first argument of rejectField is a “relative path” to the object to
Pa highlight. Why is it relevant to keep in mind that the path is relative?

Itis important to keep this in mind because the root object must be omitted from the
path. If you include the root object, then TrainingApp will not be able to find the field to
highlight.

SS Se SSeS sess e eases

configuration in the user interface and the
data model

Describe how an input mask differs from a
regular expression

Create and use an entity field validator
Describe basic validation rule behavior
Create validation rules that raise warnings
and errors

i Student exercise
